conclusion: To find the magnitude of the Ampere force received by the \(\nu\)-shaped current-carrying wire, we can follow these steps:
The wire is bent into a \(\nu\) shape with equal side lengths and an included angle of \(60^\circ\).

premise: The wire is bent into a \(\nu\) shape with equal side lengths and an included angle of \(60^\circ\).
conclusion: Each side of the \(\nu\) shape is \(l\).

premise: Each side of the \(\nu\) shape is \(l\).
conclusion: The effective length of the wire in the direction of the magnetic field is the projection of the wire length onto the direction perpendicular to the magnetic field.
For each side of length \(l\), the perpendicular component is \(l \sin(60^\circ) = l \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\).
The total effective length \(L_{\text{eff}}\) is \(2 \cdot l \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = l \sqrt{3}\).
The Ampere force \(F\) on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by \(F = B I L_{\text{eff}}\).

premise: Substitute the effective length \(L_{\text{eff}} = l \sqrt{3}\) into the formula \(F = B I L_{\text{eff}}\).
The magnitude of the Ampere force received by the \(\nu\)-shaped current-carrying wire is \(F = B I l \sqrt{3}\).
conclusion: The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on this \(\nu\)-shaped current-carrying wire is 1.
